blocks.text:
Assuming the volumetric strain to be the same everywhere,

$$ z_{ly} + z_{l} = z_{l} $$

where $z_{ly}$ is the circumferential strain, and thus $z_{l}$ is the superficial strain, and $z_{l}$ is the radial strain, then it follows that

$$ \frac{\partial z_{ly}}{\partial \theta} + \frac{\partial z_{l}}{\partial r} = 0. $$

i.e.,

$$ z_{l} = \text{Constant} = 3A (say). $$

Now

$$ 2q = \frac{\partial z_{l}}{\partial p} $$

So,

$$ 2q = \frac{-dp}{dz} $$

Separating the variables and integrating,

$$ - \int{ \frac{1}{C} \; dz} = - \log{3} + \log{(A + p)}. $$

whence

$$ (A + p) = C_{y} $$

Also,

$$ 2q = 3A + 2B \log{C_{y}} $$

i.e.,

$$ B = p + A. $$

blocks.description: Euler's formula describes the buckling load for a strut of length L and moment of inertia I.

blocks.text:
Applying the ordinary rule

$$ M = \frac{P L^2}{4 G}. $$
